caption: New water cuts aim to ease a crisis in the Colorado River and one of its reservoirs, Lake Powell, above, on the Arizona-Utah border.
image_1.context: The Colorado, which supplies water to 40 million With water levels in the Colorado River near their lowest point ever, Arizona and Nevada on Tuesday faced new restrictions on the amount of water they can pump out of the river, the most important in the Southwest. And the threat of more cuts looms. This week, those two states along with five others failed to meet a deadline for agreement on much steeper cuts in water use, raising the prospect that the federal government will step in and mandate further reductions. By HENRY FOUNTAIN States Curbed From Draining A Frail Lifeline "All the News Che New ork Cimes That's Fit to Print' VOL. CLXXI . . . No. 59,518 © 2022 The New York Times Company NEW YORK, WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 17, 2022
image_1.description: The image depicts an aerial view of Lake Powell, a reservoir located on the Arizona-Utah border. The landscape is dominated by rugged, sandstone cliffs and canyons, with deep grooves carved by the Colorado River. The water levels in the lake appear to be significantly lower than usual, revealing stark white mineral deposits along the rock faces where the waterline once was. The terrain is arid and expansive, with a vast desert stretching into the distance under a clear blue sky. The overall atmosphere conveys a sense of environmental concern due to the low water levels, highlighting the ongoing crisis in the Colorado River system.

caption: RUBBLE RAVE There was a D.J., and decorations, but the people weren’t just there for the party. They were volunteers for a Kyiv group that organizes music-infused cleanup events. Page A10.
image_2.context: The high cost of hearing aids, which are not covered by basic Medicare, has discouraged millions of Americans from buying the devices. Health experts say that untreated hearing loss can contribute to cognitive decline and depression in older people. Under the F.D.A.’s new rule, people with mild to moderate hearing loss should be able The Food and Drug Administration decided on Tuesday to allow hearing aids to be sold over the counter without a prescription to adults, a long-sought wish of consumers frustrated by expensive exams and devices. By CHRISTINA JEWETT F.D.A. Decides to Allow Over-the-Counter Sales of Hearing Aids Ukraine’s increasingly aggressive military tactics, as the government in Kyiv leans on longrange Western weapons and special forces to strike deep behind the front, disrupt Russian supply lines and counter Russia’s advantages in matériel. They also represent a growing challenge to Mr. Putin, with Crimea’s security key to Russia’s military effort — and to Mr. Putin’s political standing at home. No single action that Mr. Putin has taken in his 22-year rule provoked as much pro-Kremlin euphoria among Russians as his largely bloodless annexation of Crimea, an action that cemented his image as a leader resurrecting Continued on Page A10
image_2.description: The image depicts a group of people engaged in a cleanup activity within what appears to be a dilapidated, brick-walled area. The scene is set against a backdrop of large speakers and green crates, suggesting a music-infused event. There are at least seven individuals visible, all dressed in casual attire suitable for manual labor. Some are using shovels and buckets to dig through the dirt and debris on the ground. One person is seen filling a bucket with soil, while another is holding a shovel and bagging debris. In the background, a DJ is operating equipment, indicating that music is part of the event. The atmosphere conveys a sense of community and collaboration, as the volunteers work together amidst the ruins. The setting and activities suggest this is a volunteer event organized by a Kyiv group that combines music with cleanup efforts.

image_3.context: JACKSON, Wyo. By JONATHAN MARTIN Cheney, a Vocal Critic of Trump, Loses to a Candidate He Backed one amateur who boasted of his criminal activity on YouTube. Now, prosecutors are trying to catch up. There are currently 500 people working on pandemic-fraud cases across the offices of 21 inspectors general, plus investigators from the F.B.I., the Secret Service, the Postal Inspection Service and the Internal Revenue Service. The federal government has already charged 1,500 people with defrauding pandemic-aid programs, and more than 450 people have been convicted so far. But those figures are dwarfed by the Continued on Page A15  and forced people out of work, the federal government sent a flood of relief money into programs aimed at helping the newly unemployed and bolstering the economy. That included \$3.1 trillion that former President Donald J. Trump approved in 2020, followed by a \$1.9 trillion package signed into law in 2021 by President Biden. But those dollars came with few strings and minimal oversight. The result: one of the largest frauds in American history, with billions of dollars stolen by thousands of people, including at least Richard Ayvazyan, part of a ring that sought billions in loans, received 17 years.
image_3.description: The image shows a man in a formal setting, likely exiting or entering a building. He is dressed in a dark blue suit with a white dress shirt and a striped tie. His posture suggests he is adjusting his jacket or possibly preparing to button it. The background features a modern glass door with a metal frame, indicating an office or corporate environment. The man has short dark hair and a beard, and he appears to be looking slightly to his left with a serious expression. The lighting is bright, suggesting daytime, and the overall atmosphere conveys a sense of professionalism and formality.

image_4.context: Ukraine’s Factories Move West The government is working to save hundreds of businesses in the east from Russian bombs, creating a new industrial and economic heartland. Cuomo will not have to turn over the proceeds of his \$5.1 million deal for a book about the pandemic. PAGE A19 NATIONAL A1-23 Vows to Continue Fight  for Democracy figure she believes poses a grave threat to American democracy. Ms. Cheney conceded defeat just as The Associated Press called the race, suggesting she was setting a model for accepting the will of voters. “Harriet Hageman has received the most votes in this primary — she won,” Ms. Cheney told supporters gathered outdoors on a ranch here. She went on to implore Americans to stand up to Mr. Trump and others who deny his loss in the 2020 presidential election. “No citizen of this republic is a bystander,” she said, Continued on Page A20
image_4.description: The image shows a close-up of a person's hands as they handle a small object, which appears to be a gem or a diamond. The hands are positioned over a surface that has several similar objects scattered on it. The person is wearing a light blue shirt and a wristwatch on their left wrist. The right hand holds a pair of tweezers or a similar tool, carefully examining one of the gems. The background is out of focus, emphasizing the hands and the objects they are handling. The overall atmosphere suggests precision and careful attention to detail, possibly in a setting related to gemology or jewelry making.

image_5.description: The image depicts a meal setup featuring several plates and bowls arranged on a light-colored surface. There are three tacos on corn tortillas, each garnished with various toppings including shredded beef, cilantro, and pico de gallo. The tacos are accompanied by a bowl of fresh salsa made from diced tomatoes, onions, and cilantro. To the side, there is a wooden cutting board with sliced pieces of grilled steak, showing a charred exterior and tender interior. A knife rests on the cutting board next to the meat. Small bowls contain lime wedges and what appears to be a green herb, possibly cilantro. The overall presentation is vibrant and appetizing, suggesting a freshly prepared Mexican meal.

image_6.context: SPORTS B6-8 Fulfilling Her Potential With the W.N.B.A. playoffs about to begin, the Liberty are relying on Sabrina Ionescu, who has had a breakout season in her third year. PAGE B7 OPINION A26-27 Hannah Sung        The Supreme Court will have a chance to decide if Andy Warhol’s interpretation of a photograph of Prince is protected as a transformative work. PAGE A14 Easy-Peasy Taquiza For a no-sweat, end-of-summer party, lay out a spread of taco ingredients and let guests make their own. PAGE D2 Salvage Stores Catch On Dented cans, ignored sell-by dates, new-product flops? Frugal shoppers see only welcome bargains. PAGE D1 ARTS C1-6 Inside the ‘Saul’ Time Machine Right through its flashback-filled finale, “Better Call Saul” seamlessly looked back at how a man went wrong, and forward to where he wound up. image_6.description: The image captures a dynamic moment in a women's basketball game. Two players are in the midst of an intense play. The player on the left is wearing a white jersey with green accents and the word 'LYNX' prominently displayed, along with the number 34. She appears to be defending, with her arm extended towards the ball. Her posture suggests she is focused and ready to block or steal the ball. The player on the right is wearing a black jersey with gold accents and the word 'NEW YORK' across the chest. She has long blonde hair that is flying due to her rapid movement. She is dribbling the basketball with her right hand and seems to be making an aggressive move towards the basket. The background is dark, which helps to highlight the players and the action. The overall atmosphere conveys a sense of tension and competition typical of a high-stakes basketball game.
